qas.question: What is the priciest component of a CD?
Why did the cost of audio music increase when the production costs decreased?
What did CDs retail for in 1995?
Who received the most profit from the sale of CDs?
How much did a jewel case cost in 1995?

plausible_answers.text: the cost to produce the media was reduced

qas.question: Why were successive formats less expensive than their predecessors?
When did Apple place MP3s on the market?
What was the wholesale cost of a cassette tape?
What was the most expensive part of an MP3?
What percentage of an MP3 does Apple receive?

context: The most expensive part of a CD is the <a0_0>jewel case<a0_0/>. In <b6_0>1995<b6_0/>, material costs were <a4_0>30 cents<a4_0/> for <b8_0>the jewel case<b8_0/> and <b7_0>10 to 15 cents<b7_0/> for the CD. Wholesale cost of CDs was $0.75 to $1.15, which retailed for <a2_0>$16.98<a2_0/>. On average, <a3_0>the store<a3_0/> received 35 percent of the retail price, the record company 27 percent, the artist 16 percent, the manufacturer <b9_0>13 percent<b9_0/>, and the distributor 9 percent. When 8-track tapes, cassette tapes, and CDs were introduced, each was marketed at a higher price than the format they succeeded, even though <b5_0>the cost to produce the media was reduced<b5_0/>. This was done because the apparent <a1_0>value increased<a1_0/>. This continued from vinyl to CDs but was broken when Apple marketed MP3s for $0.99, and albums for $9.99. The incremental cost, though, to produce an MP3 is very small.
